This element controls whether the start time plus repeat - interval is automatically adjusted to account for daylight saving time. The adjustment occurs when the setting of start time is not in the same time as the current time. For example, if the current time is Pacific Daylight Time, but the start time is expressed in Pacific Standard Time, the match time is adjusted by one hour to bring the two times into agreement.

You may have granted various outside web sites access to your player(s)/content (for example, via a link offered on a page on that site). While at the same time, unauthorized sites may attempt to hijack these links (or your own local links) and publish them to their own site. This functionality allows you to specifically name qualified referrer web site URLs, thereby barring all other referrers from accessing your content.

description.html: Override Geo Controls for IP Addresses or CIDR blocks. Multiple values can be entered separated by space. Any IP Address or CIDR Block entered here will be ALLOWED regardless of their geographic location.

Enable redirect request instead of deny and input a complete page address in the Redirect URL field to serve as a deny destination. Access attempts from outside of what you have established for Geo Protection are denied and redirected to this address.
Enable this functionality to provide individual IP Addresses or CIDR blocks that should be allowed/denied access to your content.

Worldwide, IP addresses are unique to a specific geographic location. This functionality uses this concept, and leverages the IP address specific to the end-user system attempting to access your content, and either allows or denies access to it, based on this address.

Content Targeting allows you to permit or deny access to your content based on various values associated with the requesting client. For example, you can deny access to clients in a specific geographic region or allow requests coming from a specific set of IP addresses.
Specify the name of token on the incoming client HTTP request: cookie name, query string parameter name, or HTTP header name.
Specify whether the token inputs are URL escaped before generating the token. By default, inputs are URL escaped. This setting must match the setting used in the token generation code.
Specify where the token can be found on the incoming client HTTP request.
The key/shared secret used to validate the tokens. This setting must match the key used in the token generation code.

If set to Verify and Deny, a verification error causes the request to be denied. Just Verify sets the verification result in the context and specific actions can be implemented in sub rules using the Token Verification Result match.

The algorithm used for the HMAC (Hashed Message Authentication Code) to generate the token. This setting must match the method chosen in the token generation code. Caution! The algorithms from most to least secure are SHA256, SHA1, and MD5. You should not change the default of SHA256 unless you have a specific reason to do so (for example, if you have speed requirements or computational limitations on generating tokens at the origin).
Specify whether the query string is included in the URL input into the token. By default, the query string is included. This setting must match the setting used in the token generation code.
Specify a salt as input into the token for added security. This setting must match the setting used in the token generation code.

An alternate key/shared secret to validate tokens, which you can use to avoid downtime when rotating keys. Either the primary or transition key setting must match the key used in the token generation code.
Use Advanced Options.
Use Advanced Options.

caching_limitations.html: Akamai servers process GraphQL requests to detect non-cacheable content and to compute a distinct cache key component. Akamai does not process queries that exceed the maximum size of 4096 bytes or that have more than 20 nesting levels. Akamai also does not process response payloads that exceed 1024 bytes.

validation.extension_match_advised: It is recommended to only apply {{a}} under an extension matching the large object file types.  LFO adds some time overhead to serving small files.

description.html:
Large File Optimization (LFO) helps provide better performance and reliability when delivering large files.

LFO is most appropriate for objects larger than 100MB and is required for files larger than 1.8GB that are served through Akamai. It is strongly recommended that you use NetStorage to serve objects larger than 1.8GB.

rsc.jsp

http://www.eg.com/abc/*.jpg
http://eg.com/apples/main.js
*.css
*.js?

Enter page(s) to limit the pages to which Adaptive Acceleration applies Automatic Preconnect. This includes the page you specify and, if you use a wildcard, all the pages that are subpages of the specified page, for example, /images/* includes /images/cats.gif.

Please Note:
* Empty data input is not allowed.
* The default is * (asterisk for all sites).
* This setting has precedence over the Page(s) to Exclude setting.
* / must be included in the pages.

Sample pages :
/news/idx.html
/sports/golf/*
https://abc?.eeg*.com
http://www.eg.com/abc/*
http://eg.com/news/*
/category/stock.?ng

Adaptive Acceleration improves HTML page load performance by prepositioning content. When it receives an HTML page request, Adaptive Acceleration augments the response using un-intrusive techniques to provide content to the browser as needed. This reduces the load and render time for web pages based on information from the navigation and resource timing data in Real User Monitoring (RUM).

Adaptive Acceleration uses the following to increase the speed of page loading:

* Automatic HTTP/2 server push: Allows the server to send multiple responses, in parallel, for a single client request. An average web page requires multiple items, such as javaScript, CSS, and images. References to these items are in the HTML pages the server produces. Server Push allows the server to send the most important items immediately.

* Automatic Preconnect through link HTTP headers: Allows browsers to anticipate what connections the site needs and establishes those connections ahead of time, but it does not load or request anything.

The Adaptive Acceleration behavior requires that you enable both HTTP/2 and RUM on the same property.

description.html: When enabled, edge servers keep and serve stale cached objects when serving responses with status codes 400, 500, 502, 503, and 504. This allows end-user clients to access content during transient errors without re-fetching and re-caching content from the origin.
Control how error responses with status codes 204, 305, 400, 404, 405, 501, 502, 503, 504, and 505 are cached.

Set the maximum time that cached objects can remain in the cache. A setting of 0 means no-cache, which forces revalidation before serving the content. Be aware that no-cache can cause a large increase in traffic to the origin in circumstances where that would be counterproductive (for example, when the origin is returning 500 errors).
Control the caching of errors from the origin. This reduces requests for unavailable content.
Include Network Conditions in the X-Akamai-Network-Condition header when going forward to the origin following either a two-tier model (Excellent/Poor) or a three-tier model (Excellent/Fair/Poor).
This behavior instructs the Akamai platform to include Network Conditions in a special X-Akamai-Network-Condition header when going forward to the origin.

Select the action to be taken when a Public Proxy requests content. "Allow" lets these requests through, and the action is logged. (You can later audit the logs to determine how setting this to a different action may affect your traffic.) "Deny" blocks all requests from this source type. "Redirect" sends these requests to an alternate URL that you provide.
Public Proxy

Select how you want to handle requests from sources that are a match to the GeoGuard database of location spoofing proxies. "Best Practices Mode" automatically configures the four primary categories GeoGuard identifies as essential for proxy detection (Anonymous VPN, Public Proxy, The Onion Router (Tor) Exit Node and Smart DNS Proxy). "Advanced Mode" allows you to determine settings for these four primary categories individually, as well as other, optional categories to meet your specific needs. We recommend only using the optional categories if you are well-versed in GeoGuard categories and best practices.

Learn More

"Redirect" sends these requests to an alternate URL that you provide.

Verification settings apply to HTTPS requests to the origin. These settings do not apply to HTTP requests to the origin.

For example, if the certificate's CN/SAN value is www.example.com, a match value of *.example.com will not work. However, wildcards in the certificate's CN/SAN value will still be honored. For example, if the CN/SAN value is *.example.com, a match value of either *.example.com or www.example.com will work.

ssl_warn_warning.html: Choosing Do Not Verify for {{a}} SSL Certificate Verification means the edge servers will not authenticate the SSL/TLS certificate returned by the origin. Traffic between the Secure Network and your origin is vulnerable to a man-in-the-middle attack, which may expose private data. Please consult with your own security and compliance experts before selecting this option.

ssl_delegate_warning_rotate.html: If your {{a}} uses HTTPS, make sure to follow this procedure to avoid a service outage or a security breach when you rotate your origin's certificate.

shared_origin_cache_key_collision_risk.html: We've detected that you are using a shared Origin Server Hostname in {{a}}. To prevent caching issues, you are required to select Incoming Host Header as your Cache Key Hostname OR set Use Unique Cache Key to Yes.

validation.unpurgeable: Using the {{a}} behavior within a match on {{b}} will make it impossible to use the Content Control Utility to purge by URL. Please contact your Akamai Representative to explore alternative methods for making your content purgeable

ip_address_origin.html: Using an IP address for the {{a}} is not recommended. IP addresses may be changed or reassigned without notice which can severely impact your property or cause a DoS. Please use a properly formatted hostname instead.

validation.must_be_in_cloudlets_origin_group: You must set up a Conditional Origins Definition rule for the Application Load Balancer {{a}}. The Conditional Origins Definition is a child rule within the Conditional Origin Group rule template.

tcip_allow_clients_to_set_on.html: The {{a}} behavior is set to allow clients to set the True Client IP header. This means that the value sent to the origin server might not be the IP that the end user connected to the edge server with. This is useful for testing, but might allow users to bypass IP-based restrictions on your origin server if they rely on True-Client-IP.

validation.caching_maxage: For best performance when using a NetStorage {{a}}, use a {{b}} max-age over 10 minutes. If you require a max-age below 5 minutes, please contact your Akamai representative.

elb_must_use_other_cn.html: When using an Edge Load Balancing {{a}}, you cannot use {{Origin Hostname}} in Match CN/SAN To.

ssl_custom_warning_aux_list.html: When entering values in Match CN/SAN To in the {{a}} behavior, remember to also match the certificates in your property's auxiliary certificates list, which you can view on the property's home page. Failure to match those certificates may result in a service outage. Please contact your account team if you have any questions.

description.html: Specify the hostname and settings used to contact the origin once service begins. You can use your own origin, NetStorage, an Edge Load Balancing origin, or a SaaS dynamic origin.
Type of content delivered through this configuration

Catalog size (Total size of the content library delivered through this configuration)

Small: Less than 100GB

Medium: 100GB-1TB

Large: 1TB-100TB

Extra Large: Greater than 100TB

Unknown: (Default)
Individual size of objects being delivered through this property.
Optimize the delivery throughput and download times for large files.

Content popularity (how often is the content requested)

Long-Tail: Most of the traffic volume is comprised of a small number of requests for content that has a relatively long life

Popular: Most of the traffic volume is comprised of a large number of requests for content that has a relatively short life
Specify the characteristics of the content to apply content related optimizations to the property. If you are unsure, you can leave the option as 'Unknown'.

description.html: Lets you specify a custom header in requests to extract JWTs from. If you leave it disabled, the system checks the X-Akamai-DCP-Token header for JWTs.
Lets you extract a client identifier from JWTs. You use client identifiers to grant access to client identity topics.

The location in requests where the system checks first for JWTs. The selected option is a primary location, and the other option is a secondary one. If JWTs aren’t in the primary location, the system checks the secondary one.

values.client_request_header_and_query_string: Request header or query string parameter

description.html: The location in requests where you want to extract JWTs from.
The name of the claim in JWTs to extract a username from.
Lets you verify JWTs signed with the ES256 algorithm.
The name of the key collection created in the Token Access Control application. Public keys in this collection verify the integrity of the JWTs extracted from requests.
Lets you extract a username from JWTs. You use usernames to grant access to user identity topics.
The custom header in a client request to extract a JWT from.
The name of the query parameter in requests to extract JWTs from.
Lets you extract authorization groups from JWTs. You use authorization groups to govern access to specific topics.
Lets you verify JWTs signed with the RS256 algorithm.
The name of the claim in JWTs to extract a client identifier from.
The name of the claim in JWTs to extract authorization groups from.

It lets you identify and authorize clients authenticating to your origin server with JSON web tokens. You can specify a location in requests to extract JWTs from, select a collection of public keys to verify the integrity of these tokens, and decide which claims to extract for further processing.
Enables the IoT Edge Connect behavior.
Lets you publish and receive messages through a secured MQTT connection over websockets on port 443.
Lets you publish and receive messages through a secured HTTP connection on port 443.
Lets you publish and receive messages through a secured MQTT connection on port 8883.
A namespace is the name of a particular configuration. It is a sandbox containing security rules, topic configurations, etc.

It allows all connected users and devices to communicate on a publish-subscribe basis within reserved namespaces. It lets you enable the IoT Edge Connect product, select previously reserved namespaces, and decide which protocols users can use to publish and receive message within these namespaces.
Enable this to use Token Authentication without passing tokens in cookies. Tokens will be automatically passed as a part of the HLS variant manifest URIs and HLS segment URI instead.
Use Advanced Options.

Enable this to deny requests from playback URLs that contain a TokenAuth token that uses specific token identifiers. You also need to configure a "blacklist" of these token identifiers with the TokenAuth as a Service (TaaS) API to specify revoked tokens.

This uses the "Session-Id" field of the token to control access. Ensure that it is set to "Yes" in the Advanced Options > Field Carry-Over settings in this behavior. (This is the default setting.)

Learn more
Enables HLS Segment Encryption using AES-128 mode

Token Based Access Revocation

headerforsalt.label: Request Headers for Session Token Salt

description.html:
This allows you to specify additional end-user specific request headers to be used as a "salt" to generate playback-specific session tokens. Typical values include the User-Agent, X-Playback-Session-Id and Origin request headers. If you specify a header here, it needs to exist in a player request for your content, to generate the salt.

If a header is included in a player request and it's not specified here, it's ignored.

Enable this to carry-over the session_id from the access token to the session token. This allows for tracking and counting unique playback sessions.

Learn more
Encryption Mode for Media Encryption
Select the blacklist that contains the TokenAuth token identifiers that should be blocked from accessing your content.

Enable this to carry-over the ACL field from the access token to the session token. This limits the requesting client's access to the specific URL or path set in the ACL field. Note that enabling this option can result in playback failure if the base path of the master playlist (and variant playlist, plus segments) is different than what is carried over from the ACL field.

Learn more
Use Advanced Options.
Specify a salt as input into the token for added security. This value must match the salt used in the token generation code.

Enable this to carry-over information from the data/payload field from the access token to the session token. This allows access to opaque data for log analysis for a URL that is protected by a session token.

Learn more
The shared secret used to validate tokens. This value must match the key used in the token generation code or validation fails.
Validates authorization tokens at the edge server to prevent unauthorized sharing of links.

Specify the filenames for your HLS Master Manifest files. Filenames may contain alphanumeric and dot characters. You can also use an asterisk or a question mark to serve as wildcards to establish a range of filenames. Ensure that the filenames you input can be differentiated from the variant manifest files.

Note that if you don't specify a proper master manifest filename or wildcard equivalent, a request looking for it will result in an HTTP 403.
Initialization Vector used to generate the encryption key

Enable this to restrict content access to a specific IP address. Only enable this if the IP address used by the player will not change during the playback session.

Learn more
Configure settings for HLS Segments.
Use Advanced Options.
Verify and Deny returns a 403 Forbidden for any missing or invalid tokens. Use Verify Only if you want to use the Token Auth match to specify a custom action.
Field Carry-Over
An alternate shared secret to validate the tokens. This avoids downtime when rotating keys. Either the primary or transition key value must match the key used in the token generation code.
Validates authorization tokens at the edge server to prevent unauthorized sharing of links.

Enable SureRoute to identify an optimal path for performance and to establish alternative routes in the event of route failures.

Select the set of edge servers used to test routes. The default is Performance. Some special services include the option to define a custom set of edge servers (provided by your account representative).
Specify whether to use the incoming Hostheader in a custom Hostheader while requesting the SureRoute test object.

Specify the hostname to use in the Race Results Key. Typically, this is used when a single property has multiple origin hostnames in a single data center. By default, a separate race would be run for each origin. Overriding the race results hostname folds those multiple hostnames into a single hostname and therefore only one race.
Specify the Custom HOST Header that the edge server forwards to the origin when requesting the SureRoute test object.
Force SureRoute to use SSL when requesting the test object from the origin. Enable when the origin does not respond to HTTP requests, or responds with a redirect to HTTPS.

Specify the hostname to use in the Race Results Key. Typically, this is used when a single property has multiple origin hostnames in a single data center. By default, a separate race would be run for each origin. Overriding the race results hostname folds those multiple hostnames into a single hostname and therefore only one race.

Set the time-to-live (TTL) to hold the SureRoute race results. Races are only run when certain thresholds are hit. If traffic drops below the thresholds, the edge server continues to use the last race results to determine the optimal route until this TTL expires. When traffic next increases over the thresholds, the edge server uses the direct route until SureRoute determines a new optimal route. The normal setting is 30 minutes.

Set the time-to-live (TTL) to hold the SureRoute race results. Races are only run when certain thresholds are hit. If traffic drops below the thresholds, the edge server continues to use the last race results to determine the optimal route until this TTL expires. When traffic next increases over the thresholds, the edge server uses the direct route until SureRoute determines a new optimal route. The normal setting is 30 minutes.

Advanced Options allows you to further customize Application Load Balancer by giving you access to the instant retry mechanism and origin session synchronization features.

Select one:
    Automatic: If an origin fails, automatically determines which origin in the policy to try next.
  • Custom: Failover is automatic, but you define the origins to failover to, and the order in which to try them..
  • Off: Disables failover, but maintains origin stickiness even when the origin goes down. DNS layer load balancing and origin liveness testing still happen.
With failover, if no other origins are available, the request is sent to NetStorage.
Enter the ID of the origin that you want to reroute traffic from if it goes down.
Provides access to advanced features that allow you to further customize Application Load Balancer.

Select whether to select a salt for the cookie automatically. This salt is used to verify the integrity of the Origin Stickiness Cookie. This may not be desirable if you intend to share an Origin Stickiness Cookie across several digital properties.
Select On to synchronize your session cookie with the Application Load Balancer stickiness cookie.
Enable to automatically failover to any available origin. Disable to specify which origins should back up each primary origin.

Select whether to give users with an origin stickiness a fresh cookie on each request. This effectively extends the cookie as long as the user remains active. To set a fixed time for all users, do not enable this field.
Select Yes to have the Application Load Balancer stickiness cookie use the same expiration settings as your session cookie.
Select whether to enable the Application Load Balancer Cloudlet.
Sets the HttpOnly flag for the origin stickiness cookie. When enabled, the cookie is only available for true HTTP requests.

Select how to maintain origin stickiness for a user. A cookie is used for origin stickiness. For this cookie you can set an expiration date or a duration, or have the cookie never expire. If you select the re-decide membership option, no cookie is used.
If using Session Synchronization, enter a name for your session cookie (for example, JSESSIONID).

allowcacheprefresh.label: Is Content Consistent Across All Origins?

description.html: If your origins serve different content for the same URL, select No to disable cache prefresh, a type of asynchronous refresh. Otherwise, if all origins serve the same content for the same URL, select Yes. For example, if your origins all have the same file structure and content, like in an active-active data center configuration, select Yes.
Choose a NetStorage account that contains a static maintenance page.
Enter the number of individual requests that must fail or time out before Application Load Balancer reassigns the stickiness cookie to a new, available origin.

Select how to terminate the Application Load Balancer stickiness cookie. Use the ignore option to maintain stickiness to the origin when your stickiness cookie is removed or expires. Use the invalidate option to remove the  Application Load Balancer stickiness cookie when your session cookie is removed or expires.
Use this table to specify the failover mapping between data centers/origins within your Application Load Balancer configuration.

By turning Instant Failover off, Application Load Balancer will disable the instant retry capability in layer 7 only. This means Application Load Balancer will still maintain DNS layer load balancing, session stickiness will still work as will any origin session coexistence settings.
Lists session coexistence options between Application Load Balancer and your origin.

Set when a user's origin stickiness will expire. After this time the browser no longer sends the cookie. Subsequent requests are reevaluated based on the current Origin Stickiness settings.

Enter the ID of one or more origins that you want to failover to if the primary origin is down. If using multiple backup origins, enter the IDs in the order of priority.

Enabling centralized authorization allows Akamai servers to forward every request to your origin server for authorization. This could cause your servers to experience more hits, but is useful if you want to maintain tighter control over content by authorizing client requests at your origin.

hlsfilterinbitrateranges.label: Bitrates within Ranges to Keep (Filter IN)

description.html: Input a comma-separated list of bitrate ranges (in kbps) to use or filter IN with the HLS Master Manifest. (For example, 100-400,1000-4000.) Only media playlists (the #EXT-X-STREAM-INF tag) within the specified bitrate ranges are kept in the manifest.

Use this to define what should be done if all bitrates are removed as result of the various filtering operations offered here (e.g., Bitrates to Keep (Filter IN), and Bitrates within Ranges to Keep (Filter IN)). With the Show Advanced set to Yes, you can use this drop-down to select the appropriate Action.

values.origin_copy: Return the unmodified HLS master manifest
values.return_400: Return a 400 HTTP status code to the player

description.html: Enable this to reveal settings that allow you to customize the HLS Master manifest that is sent to the requesting client.

Once enabled, you can specify query string parameters in requests for the HLS Master Manifest to customize the manifest's content. The settings specified in the query string take precedence over those configured in property manager.

Example query string parameters include:

  • __b__ for 'Preferred Bitrate'
  • b-in for 'Bitrates to Keep'
  • b-in-range for 'Bitrate Ranges to Keep'

Example query string parameter usage:

  • ?__b__=500&b-in=100,200&b-in-range=500-2000

Use this option to control which media playlist (the #EXT-X-STREAM-INF tag) is listed first in the manifest.

Set this to "Opt-IN" to include Breadcrumbs data in the response headers for requests, or "Opt-OUT" to leave Breadcrumbs data out. Input the appropriate domain suffix. This is typically the same value you've input for use as your property hostname. We use this value internally to support two things:

  • Domains need to be flagged as trustworthy or acceptable ("whitelisted") for access by our Edge servers. Domain information is typically gathered from the Origin Server information defined in a base configuration. However, since an origin can be set dynamically via a policy in Akamai Cloud Embed, we whitelist the suffix you input here, and add it internally to all origin domains for this purpose.
  • We use VIP-based slot-matching in secure base configurations. As a result, URL Purge doesn’t work for vanity domains. So, you need to use this suffix to the domain names while making purge requests. For example, to purge abc.com/somepath it should be requested as abc.com.<partner domain suffix>/somepath.

description.html: Control POST Responses caching.

If the origin's response contains a Vary header with a value other than Accept-Encoding (with a corresponding Content-Encoding:gzip header), Akamai servers do not cache the response. If your origin sends Vary, but the content does not actually vary, you can use this behavior to remove it so that it can be cached.

values.poc: Cache partial objects (use with NetStorage always)

description.html: Implementation type: whether to cache chunks, that is, partial objects, or require caching of whole objects only. Partial object caching is always used when serving large objects from NetStorage. When caching partial objects, there is some risk of content corruption if the chunks come from a different version of the same file, for example, from different servers containing different versions. The origin must also properly support byte range requests.

Ignoring case in the cache key means that objects fetched with the same URL but different cases are treated as the same object in cache. Normally, the URL's path and filename are considered case-sensitive by the origin. Some origin servers, like those using Microsoft IIS, are case-insensitive. If your origin is case-insensitive, you should use this behavior.

enabled.label: Ignore Case
enabled.warning: To use this caching behavior in combination with Akamai NetStorage (or any other Unix-based server) as the origin server, you'll likely need to configure that server to also ignore the case of the URLs. For NetStorage, this is accomplished with the Force Case option, which can convert the request to either upper or lower case. Note, however, that this requires that you consistently name the files on NetStorage in either upper or lower case.

ignore_case.label: Ignore Case
ignore_case.warning: To use this caching behavior in combination with Akamai NetStorage (or any other Unix-based server) as the origin server, you'll likely need to configure that server to also ignore the case of the URLs. For NetStorage, this is accomplished with the Force Case option, which can convert the request to either upper or lower case. Note, however, that this requires that you consistently name the files on NetStorage in either upper or lower case.

validation.wm_prefetch_warning: AMD can't properly apply both the Segmented Media Streaming - Prefetch behavior and the {{a}} behavior to a single request. Avoid including both behaviors in the same rule. Also, don't apply one in the Default Rule, if the other exists in a subsequent rule in your property. This is because the Default Rule applies to all requests.
validation.msl_origin_warning: {{a}} is not supported for use with Media Services Live. Your Origin Server must be set to either "Your Origin" or "NetStorage." If you're applying a Mixed Mode use case for both Media Services Live and other Origin Servers, we recommend that you create a separate rule for your non-Media Services Live requests and include the Watermarking behavior in that rule. Do not include it in the Default Rule because it applies to all requests.

description.html: When a valid user requests content, watermarking delivers segments from multiple sources using a pattern that is unique to that user. This pattern is predetermined by a watermarking token (WMT) that is included in each request. If your content is pirated or redistributed, you can forensically analyze the segments to extract the specific pattern that was used, and identify the user that created the leak. By simply adding this behavior to your property, you've added watermarking. However, you can apply additional security measures (recommended) to verify the signature in the WMT, as well as provide details to decrypt patterns if they've been encrypted in the WMT.
This is a static behavior required for all Cloud Security Failover configuration properties to protect against any direct access. This behavior is only relevant for failover properties.

description.html: Set the threshold in seconds or bytes. The threshold is the amount of time or number of bytes you wish to pass through to the end user before applying the maximum bit rate. Best Practice: Start with a threshold of an unthrottled 5 second burst.

Bandwidth can be wasted when the video file is downloaded at a rate faster than the rate at which it is viewed. If the end user does not view the entire video, unwatched sections of the video may already have been downloaded. Bit Rate Limiting provides the ability to throttle the speed in delivering files to the end user so that there is less wasted bandwidth.

Set the threshold in seconds or bytes. The threshold is the amount of time or number of bytes you wish to pass through to the end user before applying the maximum bit rate. Best Practice: Start with a threshold of an unthrottled 5 second burst.

Set the maximum bit rate in Kbps, Mbps, or Gbps. Best Practice: Testing has shown that setting the bit rate at about 15-20% above the effective bit rate (video encode rate + audio encode rate), works well as a starting point.

Enter the query string parameters to include in or exclude from the cache key. Matches are determined by prefix matching each query string. If the query parameter with its value (name=value&) contains an item in this list (e.g., name, name=, name=value, or name=value&), then the parameter and value are included/excluded. It must also exactly match the case from the request URL, regardless of any other case-sensitivity settings.

By default, the entire query string is included in cache keys, which uniquely identify cached objects. You can instead choose to include or exclude only specific parameters, or to exclude all parameters.

what_next.html:
• After the upgrade, you will see your property in Property Manager. You can make more changes, review the settings, and save the property.
  • Click Cancel if you want to discard the upgraded property. No changes will be made to your existing configuration.
  • Activate the property to the staging environment and test thoroughly.
  • After testing is complete, activate to the production environment.
  • If you need to revert to the original configuration, activate the original configuration or the pre-upgrade configuration version.

intro.html:
Have the Luna server retrieve the certificate chain from your origin, or paste a PEM-encoded certificate directly into the box provided. If the Luna server cannot retrieve the certificate chain from your origin (e.g. if your origin has an IP allow list, such as when using SiteShield), use the paste method. To retrieve the certificate chain from your origin yourself, gather the list of IPs for your origin servers and run the following command for each:

echo | openssl s_client -showcerts -connect ORIGIN_SERVER_IP:ORIGIN_SERVER_PORT

description.html:
The Shared Certificate Hostname (e.g., www.example.com.akamaized.net) will be the hostname used in the URL used by the end users. No edge hostname or CNAME is required because the hostname will already point directly to Akamai's servers.

The Shared Certificate Hostname must end with .akamaized.net. Enter a prefix in the field.

The prefix may use only alphanumeric and hyphen characters, length 4-60. The prefix may not begin or end with a hyphen.

success_message.html:
Congratulations! You successfully modified the property hostname to edge hostname associations for your website or application. Any newly created edge hostnames will go live when you activate your configuration in either staging or production.

If you associated your property hostnames to new edge hostnames, remember to update your CNAME record. Be sure to follow these steps:

  1. Activate your configuration in staging, and wait for confirmation that the property has been activated.
  2. Test your configuration.
  3. Activate your configuration in production.
  4. Change the CNAME record of your property hostname to point to the new edge hostname.

Important! Traffic will not be directed to edge servers until this property has a complete configuration activated in the production environment. Do not update your DNS record before completing those steps. See Activating and Edge Hostnames for more information.

content.html:
You have selected to upgrade version {{b}} of {{a}} to Property Manager, our next generation configuration application.

What Happens Next?
We will automatically create a new version of your configuration in the Property Manager format based on your current Configuration Manager version {{b}}. This may take several minutes to complete, but after your new Property Manager version is created, we'll take you to the Property Manager edit page where you can review and edit the new version.

In order to complete the upgrade you will need to click Save on this page; if you choose Cancel, this new version will not be saved and everything will return to the way it was before you clicked upgrade. After reviewing the Property Manager configuration, making any desired edits, and saving, you can push it to the staging environment for testing. Once you've tested your configuration, you may push it to the production environment to finish the upgrade process.

Why Upgrade?
Property Manager provides the next level in self-service configuration for Akamai services. An entire configuration is available on a single-page interface, and intuitive drag-and-drop capabilities allow for adding and re-ordering matches and behaviors. Property Manager exposes more features for self-service and gives you more flexibility in how to combine them, unlocking the power of Akamai's EdgePlatform. Inline help and a real-time validation engine let's you know immediately how to configure your Akamai services properly and optimally. A Property Manager assistant is available that will guide you through the property creation steps. Tell Me More

intro.html:
Akamai's recent enhancements to our Secure Network platform allow greater control over which origin SSL certificates are trusted, to protect against man-in-the-middle attacks. The platform, by default, trusts certificates signed by the certificate authorities in the Akamai Certificate Store that also have a CN/SAN matching the Forward Host Header. You can maximize security for your property by directly controlling which certificates our edge servers should trust. If this property uses Property Manager, please edit it to add specific certificates Akamai should trust (learn more). If this property uses Configuration Manager, please call your account team.

The Auxiliary Certificate List below contains the certificates Akamai pinned on your behalf. They will be trusted in addition to certificates otherwise trusted by your property, and Akamai will periodically remove certificates that are no longer necessary for your property from the Auxiliary Certificate List. This list is not editable by customers; please contact your account team to remove certificates from this list. Learn more

Auxiliary Certificates List

objects_cant_exceed_1mb.html:
When using {{a}}, please be advised that the ESI objects may not exceed 1MB in size.

Additionally, with Detect ESI Injection option enabled, Akamai Edge servers will examine inbound request attributes (headers, query strings, cookies, entity bodies) for unexpected ESI tags. If ESI Injection is perceived, this feature will deny offering requests. This is only an issue if your content origin reflects unsanitized request attributes into the response.

origin_valid_cn_wildcard.html: The values you provide in the {{a}} behavior's Match CN/SAN To field can contain a star (*) character, but it will act as a literal character and not as a wildcard. For example, if the certificate's CN/SAN value is www.example.com, a match value of *.example.com will not work. However, wildcards in the certificate's CN/SAN value will still be honored. For example, if the CN/SAN value is *.example.com, a match value of either *.example.com or www.example.com will work.

description.html: Identify content that may contain personal or private information or other data that should not be cached. Several criteria you can use and modify to match your needs. purpose.html:
Manifest Personalization customizes the HLS Master Manifest file for playback according to the best practices for individual players and playback environments. These best practices control the bitrate playlists that will be included in the HLS master manifest and also specify the preferred bitrate (the bitrate listed at the top amongst other bitrates).

Custom rules can also be specified to override the best practices.

description.html: This template identifies typical origin failure situations like timeout or specific 5XX response codes. The failover action taken in this situation is to forward the request to another hostname within the property and modify the request path to serve a specific sorry page or an alternate content. The downstream caching is prevented to avoid the alternate content from being cached by browsers and intermediate (non Akamai) HTTP proxies. Replace the example response codes, hostname and alternate content values as appropriate and required.

purpose.html: Indicate whether or not a browser should be allowed to render a page in a <frame> or <iframe>

description.html: The X-Frame-Options HTTP response header can be used to indicate whether or not a browser should be allowed to render a page in a <frame> or <iframe>. Sites can use this to avoid clickjacking attacks, by ensuring that their content is not embedded into other sites.

description.html: This template performs Location Based forwarding. Since the User location is determined by the edge server, the usage of the X-Location header allows to propagate the information about the location to the parent Akamai Servers. The use of Modify incoming request header avoids the duplication of headers as the request travels upstream.

If

  • path matches /examplepath/*
  • AND

Then Cache for 365 days (or set a different value).

It also computes a cache-key based on a canonical query (from SHA256 hash). This computed cache-key may improve the cache hit rate. When Multiple GraphQL client implementations access the same server, the GraphQL query string of an equivalent request may be formed in different ways.

description.html:
This template removes an incoming Pragma request header if it contains any Akamai-related values. This ensures that X-Akamai-Session-Info headers will not be included in the response, as these debugging headers can contain information that you may not want to be 'leaked' to an end-user.

You can choose under what circumstances the Pragma header should be removed - by default it will be removed unless the X-Akamai-Debug: true request header is also passed.

For added security, you should change this rule to specify a secret value for the X-Akamai-Debug header - for instance X-Akamai-Debug: ASecureValue12345 - to minimize the chance that an end-user may guess the value. You can also include additional matches for allowed IP addresses to further limit the circumstances under which the Pragma header should not be removed.

purpose.html: Removes debug information from response headers, to avoid unwanted information leakage

description.html: Bandwidth can be wasted when the video file is downloaded at a rate faster than the rate at which it is viewed. If the end user does not view the entire video, unwatched sections of the video may already have been downloaded. Bit Rate Limiting provides the ability to throttle the speed in delivering files to the end user so that there is less wasted bandwidth.

Managing a lot of redirects? Consider the Edge Redirector Cloudlet which allows you to easily manage a large volume of URL redirects to be performed by the Akamai Intelligent Platform at the network edge, reducing request service time and network load. Quickly set and activate flexible rules based on your needs, and even alleviate strain on IT teams by extending this control to Marketing or other administrators to manage.

ak_tls_cipher_name.label: TLS Cipher Name

ak_tls_preferred_ciphers.description: The value of the tag security:essl.slot-assignment.preferred-ciphers for this request.
ak_tls_preferred_ciphers.label: Preferred Ciphers

ak_origin_dns_name.label: Origin DNS Name
ak_origin_dns_name.description: The hostname the Akamai server resolved to go forward to the origin.

ak_request_id.label: Request ID
ak_request_id.description: The unique ID of the request on the Akamai server.

ak_tls_sni_name.description: The SNI name submitted by the client.
ak_tls_sni_name.label: TLS SNI Name

ak_host_cname_chain.description: A space delimited list of the CNAME chain provided by DNS lookup on the incoming Host: header.
ak_host_cname_chain.label: Host CNAME Chain

ak_scheme.description: Request Scheme, either http or https
ak_scheme.label: Scheme

ak_current_time.label: Current Time
ak_current_time.description: The current epoch time as of application of metadata to the request. If needed, epoch time can be converted to other time formats with the Set Variable behavior, using the "Epoch to String" option.

ak_original_url.description: URL as Akamai Edge server sees it before any processing.
ak_original_url.label: Original URL

ak_client_ip.description: Client IP address seen by the Akamai server. Can be overridden by the X-Forwarded-For and Akamai-Client-IP request headers.
ak_client_ip.label: Client IP

ak_connected_client_ip.description: Contains the IP on the TCP socket whether it be a redirecting ghost or a client.
ak_connected_client_ip.label: Connected Client IP

ak_protocol_negotiation.label: Protocol Name
ak_protocol_negotiation.description: The protocol negotiated with the client when NPN or ALPN is used. The variable value is available from client request stage forward. Possible values include, for http2: h2-14 or h2, for spdy: spdy/3.1 or spdy/3 or spdy/2, for http: http/1.1 or http/1.0

ak_domain.description: Hostname minus the first subdomain and dot. For example, example.com if the request hostname was www.example.com.
ak_domain.label: Domain Name

ak_firewall_detected_rules.label: Firewall Detected Rules
ak_firewall_detected_rules.description: A colon-separated list of rule IDs for firewall rules that were detected for the current request.

ak_method.label: Method
ak_method.description: Request Method: GET, PUT, POST, HEAD, etc.

ak_path.label: Path
ak_path.description: Path of the URL as seen by Akamai Edge server

ak_maprule.label: Map Rule
ak_maprule.description: The maprule for the incoming request. For example, "a123.g.akamai.net".

ak_filename.label: Filename
ak_filename.description: The filename of the incoming request

ak_firewall_triggered_rules.label: Firewall Triggered Rules
ak_firewall_triggered_rules.description: A colon-separated list of rule IDs for firewall rules that were triggered for the current request.

ak_ghost_service_ip.description: The edge server IP address used to forward a request. This is the IP address the origin server will see as the client IP when it receives a request from Akamai.
ak_ghost_service_ip.label: Ghost Service IP Address

ak_firewall_mitigated_rules.label: Firewall Mitigated Rules
ak_firewall_mitigated_rules.description: A colon-separated list of rule IDs for firewall rules that were mitigated for the current request.

ak_extension.description: Filename extension of the incoming request
ak_extension.label: Extension

aka_pm_cacheable_object.label: Cacheable Object
aka_pm_cacheable_object.description: true, if object is cacheable, false if it isn't.

ak_firewall_alerted_rules.label: Firewall Alerted Rules
ak_firewall_alerted_rules.description: A colon-separated list of rule IDs for firewall rules that triggered an alert for the current request.

ak_client_real_ip.description: The client IP address seen by the Akamai server. Request headers are ignored.
ak_client_real_ip.label: Real Client IP

info.html: This assistant will guide you in setting up your property.

message.html:
• To navigate, select a page number or click the forward or back arrow buttons.
  • To exit at any time, Select Exit Assistant.

You can edit existing rules or click Add Rule to add a new rule. You can click the Add Behavior button to view a library of features that provide the instructions for handling the objects requested from your site or application.

info.html: Rules give you the ability to define the content to which to apply particular behaviors. You set up matches based on criteria such as file extensions, and then apply the behaviors you want. For more information, see the on-line help.

rules.title: Rules
rules.next_text: Click the forward arrow to learn about creating and editing rules.

review.title: Review Mode
review.next_text: Click the forward arrow to learn about using the Review Mode.

message.html: Review mode allows you to see your configuration in a birds-eye view, allowing you to quickly review the entire tree rather than viewing a single rule's contents. A behavior filter allows you easy access to all instances of a behavior used in your configuration.

During or after editing, click the Save button to save your current settings. You can save your configuration with validation errors, but you will not be able to activate the property until validation errors are cleared. If you get errors that don't allow you to save, you'll need to fix the problem and then try to save again.

After you save, you can continue to edit or edit later, or move on to review and activate, or take other actions.

save.title: Saving your configuration settings
save.next_text: Click the forward arrow to learn about creating and editing your property configuration.

sureroute.next_text: Click the forward arrow to learn about configuring SureRoute behavior.

info.html: When SureRoute is enabled, Akamai edge servers can use at least two alternate routes to the origin in addition to the established direct route in order to increase performance by using the most effective route. The edge server occasionally runs races between the routes to fetch test objects to determine the best route. For more information, see the on-line help.

message.html: If you have placed a SureRoute test on your origin, enter its location in the SureRoute behavior.

sureroute.title: Configuring SureRoute Behavior

message.html:
To associate edge hostnames with your property hostnames:

  1. In the Property Hostnames section of the Edit tab, click the Add button.
  2. Follow the instructions in the Property Hostnames wizard.

hostnames.title: Add Property Hostname to Edge Hostname Association
hostnames.next_text: Click the forward arrow to learn about property hostnames.

info.html: A property hostname is the name of the site or application the end users request when they click a link or type a URL into their browser address bar. You need to associate each of your property hostnames with an edge hostname. For more information about property hostnames, see the online help.

ipv6.next_text: Click the forward arrow to learn about the IPv6 Option.
ipv6.title: IPv6 Option

info.html:
Transition your content to be automatically delivered using IPv6.

IPv4 sites will be able to take advantage of high performance, high availability IPv6 delivery without making significant changes to your origin infrastructures.

message.html: Make sure the IPv6 Option is checked to enable IPv6 for your site.

landing_button.title: Property Home Page
landing_button.next_text: Click the forward arrow to learn about navigating to the Property Home page.

message.html: Click the Back to Property button on the upper right to review property information. From here you can view the state of your service, manage property versions or perform other tasks.

origin.title: Specify Origin Server Settings

info.html: The origin server hostname points to the same IP address as the origin server. It is the address from which Akamai will retrieve content. For additional help, see the on-line help.

message.html: When you create or change an origin server, enter all required information for each field. You can do that now or later with the origin-server behavior on the Edit tab.

origin.next_text: Click the forward arrow to learn about origin server settings.

message.html:
The assistant is now complete. Watch the Luna Property Manager Walkthrough video for further assistance.

Select Exit Assistant to continue working on your property.

cpcode.next_text: Click the forward arrow to learn about CP codes.
cpcode.title: Select CP Code

message.html: Select a CP Code by clicking the edit icon and choosing it.

info.html: The CP Code is used for reporting and billing of your content and is a required setting in order to active and use property. For more information, see the on-line help.

secure.title: Secure Option
secure.next_text: Click the forward arrow to learn about the Secure Option.

message.html: Make sure the Secure Option is checked to enable SSL for your site.
You navigate and work on a specific property version created after copying a property configuration to a new version.

tabs.title: Navigating Property Manager
tabs.next_text: Click the forward arrow to learn more about navigating the Property Manager.

info.html: The Edit and Activate tabs allow you to navigate the Property Manager task areas.
You can switch among Edit, Review, and View XML modes by clicking on the applicable button.

edit_review.next_text: Click the forward arrow to learn about switching among Edit, Review, and View XML modes.
edit_review.title: Edit, Review, and View XML
